author: Sasha Abramsky is writing a book on changing attitudes toward crime and the expansion of the American prison system, to be published by St. Martin's Press.
body: AS the millennium draws to a close, a handful of New Yorkers prepare to enter their second century. Born in the 1890's, in the waning years of the Victorian era, they survived the turbulence of the 20th century and now, in their 11th decade, they prepare for the 21st. A century from now, centenarians may be a dime a dozen. But in 1999, they are
title: New York, When They Were Young

body: At Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn, the biohazard suits have been fitted, and the decontamination showers have found an outdoor home near the emergency room bay. Almost two dozen doctors, nurses and other hospital staff members have been through a rigorous two-day training program in protecting themselves and treating victims of a chemical
title: Hospitals Prepare for All the Possibilities

body: The overall crime rate in New York City declined again this year, but a rise in homicides and several other factors have led some criminologists to question whether the decade-long descent is about to bottom out. Through Dec. 12, crime has fallen by 8 percent over last year, police statistics show. But during that same period, the homicide rate,
title: Experts Wonder if Crime Drop Is Near End

body: Rembrandts, Anyone? Any seasoned collector of old masters will remember the two auctions of extraordinary drawings from Chatsworth, the Derbyshire home of the Duke of Devonshire, at Christie's in London in 1984 and 1987. Both were landmark sales at which institutions like the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles and collectors like Ian Woodner
title: INSIDE ART

body: David Rousseve grew up hearing his Creole grandmother's tales about old times and old folk. Her spirit has informed much of his dance and theater work over the last decade. It is present in his ambitious new ''Love Songs,'' which opened on Thursday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Harvey Lichtenstein Theater. The two-hour work begins with a
title: DANCE REVIEW; Love Stories Outlasting Their Time And Place

body: Maggie Lee, a 60-year-old Harlem resident, spends her days as an aide to an 86-year-old woman who lives in Washington Heights. When she gets home, she looks after four grandchildren and her husband, who had his left leg amputated below the knee because of diabetes. This was not the sort of hectic schedule that Ms. Lee had envisioned for herself as
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; At Threshold of Old Age, Still Caring for Children

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CONEY ISLAND; Backers of Amateur Arena See Ballpark Plan as Lever

body: Two years ago Betsy Thomas, a television writer, checked into the Chateau Marmont hotel in West Hollywood in the aftermath of a divorce. On her first evening there she called room service for a bottle of wine when friends visited. The waiter, an unemployed actor, arrived with the tray. One thing led to another. Ms. Thomas not only married the
title: Getting Personal in Prime Time; Creators of TV Shows Tap Their Lives

body: The trumpeter, band leader and composer Lester Bowie, an icon of the experimental movement in jazz from the mid-1960's on who was also known for his comic shows and jazz-based treatments of pop music, died on Monday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 58. The cause was liver cancer, said his brother Byron. Best known as a member of the Art Ensemble of
title: Lester Bowie Is Dead at 58; Innovative Jazz Trumpeter

body: An off-duty police officer shot a Brooklyn man yesterday morning on a street corner at the crowded Fulton Street Mall after the man tried to rob him, the police said. The officer, Varlos Brathwaite of the 88th Precinct in Fort Greene, was shopping when he was approached by Tobia J. Evans, 22, of Flatbush, who pulled out a knife and asked for his
title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK; Off-Duty Officer Shoots Man Confronting Him

body: During the first prayer service at the Ha'l Sufi Masjid in Bedford-Stuyvesant last month, the front door was left open so the curious could poke in their heads. The gesture was significant, a sign that the newcomer hoped to establish a visible presence in the neighborhood. The Ha'l Sufi Masjid had previously occupied temporary quarters on
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BEDFORD-STUYVESANT; A Mosque With a Social Mission and an Open-Door Policy

body: Until she opened her natural body care business, Carol's Daughter, in a storefront in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, Lisa M. Price used her living room in Bedford-Stuyvesant as a showcase. She still mixes her recipes by hand in her kitchen, just as she did when she started in 1993. Mrs. Price (whose mother is named Carol) opened Carol's Daughter in August
title: NEW YORKERS & CO.; Like Mother, Like Daughter: Handmade Body Care

title: DANCE REVIEW; As Willful As Ever And Puffing On a Cigar

title: Fort Greene Is Not A Culinary Wasteland

title: THEATER REVIEW; Metaphysical Wrestling, With No Holds Barred

title: THEATER REVIEW; An Irish Classic Given Cartoon Form

title: RESIDENTIAL REAL ESTATE; Turning Old School Into Apartments

body: NEVER had a nervous breakdown looked so glamorous. It was one thing to fall to pieces onstage; characters in plays had been doing that since ''Oedipus Rex.'' But it was something else to come unglued in exquisite evening clothes while stormily playing the piano, with a chic little gold box filled with something illegal in your pocket. Nicky
title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; Blithe Spirit As Life Force

body: Ten houses built between 1864 and 1901 in the Brooklyn Navy Yard have been left to decay since the yard closed in 1966. In recent years, the only occupants of the three-story structures, which once housed senior naval officers and their families, have been packs of stray dogs and the occasional homeless person. Edward Carter, a director of the
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FORT GREENE; Spit and Polish Sought for Navy Homes

title: For the Living, Cemeteries Were Oases of Calm

While his friends were often busy playing basketball, he fell in love with tennis in
title: U.S. OPEN: NOTEBOOK; Early Dose of Tennis

title: POSTINGS: Addition for School of Education on Brooklyn Campus; A New Building for L.I.U.

body: Thai and Vietnamese restaurants are easy to find in New York, while the number of Malaysian restaurants seems to be growing all the time. title: EATING OUT; South by Southeast

The advertisements, which feature the phone number for the domestic-violence hot line run by
title: Madison Avenue Creates Stark Ad About Battering

body: HE swings open a small red gate at the end of the subway platform, ignoring the warning that reads ''Do Not Enter or Cross Tracks,'' and enters the dank tunnel just west of the Lafayette Avenue station in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn. A green light illuminates the youthful contours of his face as he saunters down the last narrow wedge of forbidden
title: From the Subways to the Streets

body: The normally stoic guards at the Metropolitan Museum of Art rarely look like they are having fun. ''I see them
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; Scavengers on a Trail of Wit

body: IN villages across Africa, storytelling has long been an integral part of daily life. At nights, even to this day, people gather in circles in courtyards illuminated by a full moon and bright stars to hear gripping tales from wise men and indelible stories from adventurous young men who have returned to their hamlets from faraway places. This and
title: New Roots for Black Culture

title: Lottery Dispute Chills Workers' Camaraderie

body: On the Move Larry Forgione's An American Place may have become the city's most peripatetic restaurant: it has just moved for the third time since it opened in 1983 on Lexington Avenue near 70th Street. It has been lured from its warmly honeyed, polished-wood room at 32d Street and Park Avenue to a warmly honeyed, polished-wood room in the new
title: OFF THE MENU

title: Mall Builder Sees New Brooklyn, but Neighbors See Trouble

body: Brandi Taylor, 14, knows that AIDS lurks close to home. She is so concerned about it that when she recently explored getting a tattoo, she asked the tattoo artist if he would clean his needles in front of her. But she knows that she is more likely to contract the disease through sex. Most of her peers, she says, started having sex when they were 12
title: Spreading the Word on AIDS

title: FAMILY FARE

body: From White Cells To Weimaraners It's not often that you see a film whose heroine is a beautiful white blood cell. Or animation inspired by Kafka. But these works and more will be offered this weekend in the BAMkids Film Festival, presented at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. ''The idea of combining the new and the known drove all the choices,'' said
title: FAMILY FARE

body: Calling New York City's limited crackdown on unleashed dogs a success, Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern said yesterday that the program would be expanded to several parks around the city. Though the initial crackdown focused on Riverside and Central Parks in Manhattan, the targets this time will include several parks that are outside Manhattan:
title: City to Expand Its Crackdown on Dogs

body: When Chimene slips into her mourning clothes in Declan Donnellan's revelatory new production of ''Le Cid,'' it is not an anonymous servant who dresses her. It is the man for whom she grieves, her father, Don Gomes, slain in a duel with her lover, who helps her off with her undergarments and on with her black shoes and dress. In the instant of this
title: THEATER REVIEW; Love, Honor and Duty In Codified Old Castille

body: It was not Mae-Ann Gilbert's worst subway ride. That, she said, would have been the morning rush hour in 1988 when the No. 3 train struck and killed a woman and other passengers cursed the victim for making them late. Nor was it her most unpleasant experience in a contest. That came in 1984, she said, when she was the first-ever black contestant in
title: Luck and the B Train Win a Race for a Yankee Fan

body: A psychiatric patient in a Brooklyn hospital who confessed to his therapist on Sunday that he had killed a woman was arrested on murder charges after officers found the body of a woman who had been stabbed to death in her apartment, the police said yesterday. The patient, Matthew Felix, 32, was paroled in January after serving time for a 1985
title: Patient Charged in a Killing After Confessing to His Therapist

title: Diallo Family to Get Preview of Charges From the District Attorney

title: After Fire, Delays on Subway Stir Grumbling Among Riders

body: His name is on the lips of the hip-hop set in Sunset Park. The teen-agers in the baggy pants and Michelin Man jackets up and down Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn know Pedro Quinones, though not as Pedro Quinones. They know him as Casper, the sultan of the shape-up, the master of the Number One Fade, the quick answer to the bad hair day. He is only 19,
title: Building Fame for $15 a Head; For the Hip-Hop Set, the Local Celebrity Is the Barber

body: To say that ''Promised Land'' is avant-garde theater is putting it mildly. The actors never show their faces (the curtain rises by degrees, but only as high as shoulder level); they speak not a single word, and, oh yes, the lead character is a rock. Perhaps most surprising, however, is that the play is for family audiences. ''Children are always
title: FAMILY FARE; If This Stone Could Speak

body: Erick Barkley and Tyrone Grant, their low voices spiked with bravado, had a conversation recently that turned civic pride on its head -- debating which one of them came from the worse Brooklyn neighborhood. title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: He's Got the Moves Off Court, Too; St. John's Point Guard Conquers a Road Fraught With Danger

body: Faried Assad and Ahmad Samhan are partners and cousins, and live in Brooklyn, Mr. Assad in Carroll Gardens and Mr. Samhan in Fort Greene. Zaytoons is at 283 Smith Street (near DeGraw Street) in Mr. Assad's neighborhood,
title: NEW YORKERS & CO.; In One Brooklyn Restaurant, Three Corners of Arab World

body: ON a water-logged day in Brooklyn, everything seems muted and muffled -- the grays and browns of the buildings, the soggy drumbeat of the rain, the leaden thwock of the car wheels shooting out sprays of oily water as they rumble over manhole covers. And then there is Rosie Perez, who, rain or shine, is about as muted and muffled as a stick of
title: FILM; Trying to Shake a Stereotype But Keep On Being Rosie Perez

title: DANCE; On a Brooklyn Mission To Be a Good Neighbor

body: Weeks after attacking New York State's new charter school law on the ground that it would drain money from the rest of the public school system, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew announced an ambitious charter program for New York City yesterday. He said he would set up four new charter schools focusing on themes including music, business and animation;
title: Giving Up Attack, Crew Offers His Charter School Plan

title: THEATER REVIEW; Finding Appalling Sense in a Giddy Anarchy

title: From Humor to Drama, a Woman's View From Around the World

body: Just six weeks after Gov. George E. Pataki pushed a charter school law through the State Legislature, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew is proposing to set up his own charterlike school districts in Brooklyn, granting them freedom from the central school bureaucracy in an effort to improve student achievement, school officials said yesterday. Dr. Crew's
title: Crew Plans Charter Schools, His Way

title: Parks Chief Promises a Tree for the Asking to All Homeowners

title: For New York, 25-Year Losing Streak

body: Who is that sleek young time bomb of a man? At moments, he seems as frightened and helpless as a 4-year-old who has lost his parents at the fair; at other times, he is the soul of patrician urbanity, your ideal white-tie dinner partner. Then the eruptions come in nasty bolts of anger. And they aren't half as scary as when his face freezes into a
title: THEATER REVIEW; On the Cusp Of Monsterhood With Nero

body: If you live in the world of Jean Racine, the 17th-century French tragedian, you definitely don't want to mess with Venus. The goddess of love is also, as one of the dramatist's characters puts it, the ''goddess of pure remorseless cruelty.'' She's implacable and unbeatable, and she takes no prisoners. That doesn't stop the ever imperious Diana
title: THEATER REVIEW; In 'Phedre,' A Mix of Lust, Anger and Chic

body: AS an elder-law attorney in the resort town of Truth or Consequences, N.M., John C. Wheeler can't help but spend most of his time thinking about retirement. title: The New Faces of Retirement

body: New York's New Year's Eve party was a cold, crowded and -- at one point -- smoky, but largely peaceful trial run for the celebration planned for next year to welcome in 2000, according to police officials. The 5,000 police officers who patrolled the party -- one of the largest police details in history -- made fewer arrests than the year before, 23
title: In Run-Through for Next Year, Mostly Sedate Merrymaking in Times Square
